Building a Microsite¶

This fabfile defines methods for automated tasks, allowing for easier building, publishing, etc. of the pelican site.

To specify the location of the site content, set the PATH option when invoking fabric, which will be passed on to Pelican, overriding the pelicanconf.PATH attribute in the config file.

For example:

fab build --set=PATH="path/to/content\ escaping\ spaces/"
fabfile.clean()[source]¶

Deletes the output directory and makes a new, empty one

fabfile.build()[source]¶

Builds the site (locally) using the default local config file

fabfile.debug()[source]¶

Cleans and then builds locally with the debug flag on, to show all debug messages

fabfile.rebuild()[source]¶

Clear output directory, then build locally

fabfile.regenerate()[source]¶

Re-build whenever a file is saved; useful for local testing

fabfile.serve()[source]¶

Serve the output directory at localhost:8000. Use for local testing

fabfile.reserve()[source]¶

Build then serve

fabfile.preview()[source]¶

Build the site locally as if publishing to the server. Use this to see what the files would look like on the remote server, without actually changing the contents of the server. Note that, since resources are referred to by their URL on the server, rather than their file location, some things won’t load locally, or will load possibly unchanged versions from the live server.

fabfile.publish(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Publish to website To call this, you either need to have SSH set up, or use the following options when invoking fabric:

-I switch to have password entered initially, or
-p switch with the password.

For example:

fab publish -I

Prompt for password first, though the password won’t actually be checked that it’s correct

fab publish -p mypassword

Pass mypassword through to publish site without prompting (where actual password replaces mypassword)

Note

This requires winscp to be downloaded for Windows machines, including the command-line utility

Note

This method calls the sync_output_to_remote.script WinSCP script, which will actually sync the output directory with the destpath path on the remote server. destpath is set in the secretconf config file.
